xyz.acygn.mokapot.util

Class PooledThread

  • java.lang.Object
    • xyz.acygn.mokapot.util.PooledThread
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    JoinablePooledThread

    public class PooledThread
extends Object
    A Thread-like object that executes using a thread pool, rather than as a thread of its own.
    Author:
    Alex Smith

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Modifier Constructor and Description
      protected PooledThread()
      Creates a new thread pool task for which the code to run is specified by overriding the run() method.
        PooledThread(Runnable code)
      Creates a new thread pool task that mimics a thread, given the code to run.

    • Constructor Detail

      • PooledThread

        protected PooledThread()
        Creates a new thread pool task for which the code to run is specified by overriding the run() method. Because it requires overriding a method, this constructor should only be called by a derived class and not directly.

      • PooledThread

        public PooledThread(Runnable code)
        Creates a new thread pool task that mimics a thread, given the code to run.
        Parameters:
        code - The code that's run by this "thread".

    • Method Detail

      • rotateThreadPool

        public static void rotateThreadPool()
        Causes all threads currently in the thread pool to no longer be reused. They will be terminated immediately (if dormant), or upon execution ceasing (if not dormant). This method is useful when the system is about to shut down, as it will prevent threads in the thread pool that are waiting to be reused from blocking system shutdown.

        Further use of PooledThreads is possible, but they will be run on an entirely different set of Java threads (i.e. "rotating" the thread pool to use a different set of threads).

      • start

        public void start()
        Starts running this thread pool task, on an existing but dormant thread if one is available, or creating a new one if none are available. Any ResettableThreadLocal storage objects will be told to consider the used thread to be a new thread, thus causing it to act as though it were new even if it was actually recycled.

        Each individual task should only be run once. Create a duplicate task if you wish to run a task again.

      • run

        protected void run()
        Performs the tasks of this thread pool task. By default, this runs the tasks specified in the constructor, but it can be overridden to specify alternate tasks to run (just like with Thread).
